expectations:
- Prepare students for web developer roles
      - MUST be in US English

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model C is the most comprehensive and well-structured curriculum. It has ~88 chapters covering an exceptional breadth and depth. Key strengths: (1) Excellent granularity - separates frontend security from backend security, authentication from authorization, SQL performance from relational modeling, database migrations as its own topic, distributed data fundamentals, etc. (2) Includes often-overlooked but critical topics: data/text fundamentals, browser internals, web privacy/consent, analytics/experimentation, internationalization, domain modeling/DDD, file/media services, payments, email/notifications, incident management, SRE, infrastructure as code, practical cryptography, compliance/governance, cloud cost optimization, documentation, engineering leadership, WebRTC, real-time collaboration (CRDTs), web graphics/visualization. (3) Follows vendor neutrality well - no specific tool names except Git. (4) Titles are concise and professional. (5) Descriptions are direct, no fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore'. (6) Logical progression from foundations to advanced. (7) Includes career chapter. (8) Covers scaling, search systems, caching strategies, networking for web systems - topics needed for true mastery. Minor issues: some descriptions could be slightly more concise, and the sheer volume is large but justified for a 'top 1%' curriculum. Overall, this is the most complete curriculum that would genuinely prepare someone for senior/staff-level roles.

Model D is extremely comprehensive with ~82 chapters, rivaling Model C in breadth. Key strengths: (1) Excellent topic separation - DNS/domain management, concurrency control, load/stress testing, production readiness, operational excellence, modernizing legacy apps, API gateway/BFF, experimentation/feature management, scaling frontend codebases, monorepos. (2) Good vendor neutrality. (3) Concise titles and descriptions mostly free of fluff. (4) Includes career chapter and leadership chapter. (5) Covers unique practical topics like 'Working with product and design', 'Modernizing legacy web apps', 'Engineering for testability'. Minor issues: (1) Some topics feel slightly over-granulated (e.g., 'Web across devices' and 'Mobile web optimization' could potentially merge). (2) A few descriptions use slightly verbose phrasing. (3) Title 'i18n and l10n' uses abbreviations that may not be as clear. Overall very strong and comprehensive, nearly on par with Model C but slightly less polished in organization.

Model E is very comprehensive with ~61 chapters. Strengths: (1) Good coverage across frontend, backend, DevOps, architecture, security, and career topics. (2) Includes TypeScript, design systems, i18n, PWAs, WebAssembly, privacy/compliance, testing at scale. (3) Includes unique chapters like 'Business and Product Literacy for Engineers', 'Ethics and Inclusive Engineering', 'Open Source Contribution'. (4) Mostly vendor-neutral. Issues: (1) Title 'Developer Environment and Linux' specifically names Linux, which is a vendor choice - should be more neutral. (2) Last chapter 'Production Readiness and Professional Practice' mentions 'portfolio of systems' which feels like a capstone/project, violating the no-capstone rule. (3) 'Master-level engineering topics' title references mastery level which, while not saying 'top 1%', is close to referencing prompt instructions. (4) Some descriptions have filler words: 'Role of web development, history of the web' in the overview chapter. (5) Databases combined into one chapter ('Databases and Data Modeling') is less granular than ideal. (6) Missing some specific topics like browser storage, forms/validation as dedicated chapters, search systems. Still a very solid curriculum overall.

Model G has ~78 chapters with extensive coverage. Strengths: (1) Very comprehensive across all areas. (2) Includes many practical topics: email integration, file handling, payments, data visualization, WebGL, web components. (3) Career chapter included. (4) Good progression. Issues: (1) Major vendor neutrality violations - explicitly names React (two chapters: 'React Fundamentals' and 'Advanced React Patterns'), Redux, Zustand, React Query/TanStack Query, Next.js, Nuxt, Remix, Astro, Vue.js, Angular, Express, Webpack, Vite, Rollup, Parcel, Sass, Less, Three.js, React Native, Capacitor, npm, yarn, pnpm, Kubernetes, Docker (named in titles), Helm, Swagger. This is a significant violation of vendor neutrality rules. (2) Having React-specific chapters plus an 'Alternative Frontend Frameworks' chapter for Vue/Angular shows bias. (3) Some titles are verbose: 'CSS Layout: Flexbox & Grid', 'Relational Databases & SQL' (SQL is implied per task expectations). (4) Some descriptions use mildly verbose phrasing. The vendor neutrality violations are substantial and systematic, which is a major penalty per the prompt rules.

Model F has ~55 chapters with decent coverage. Strengths: (1) Good logical progression. (2) Covers most key areas. (3) Includes career chapter, emerging trends. (4) Mostly clean descriptions. Issues: (1) Title 'Containerization with Docker' explicitly names Docker, violating vendor neutrality. (2) 'Node.js & Package Management' names Node.js - could be more neutral as 'Server-Side Runtime & Package Management'. (3) Title 'Relational Databases & SQL' - SQL is implied per task expectations. (4) Some titles are verbose: 'Frontend Frameworks & Component Architecture', 'Rendering Strategies: SSR, SSG & CSR'. (5) Missing important topics for top 1%: no infrastructure as code, no search systems, no domain modeling/DDD, no caching strategies (dedicated), no incident management/SRE, no data protection/cryptography, no background jobs/queues. (6) Less granular than top models - databases crammed together, security in one chapter. (7) Description 'Building websites that adapt to any screen size' is slightly fluffy. Overall adequate but lacks the depth and breadth needed for a truly comprehensive curriculum.

Model B has 32 chapters, which is relatively lean. Strengths: (1) Clean, concise titles. (2) Good vendor neutrality. (3) Covers core topics well. (4) Includes system design, container orchestration as separate chapter. (5) Includes ORM, WebAssembly, caching & edge computing. Issues: (1) Only 32 chapters is insufficient for a 'top 1%' curriculum - many important topics are missing or inadequately covered. (2) Missing: TypeScript, forms/validation, design systems, i18n, browser storage, infrastructure as code, incident management, domain modeling, event-driven architecture, background jobs, search systems, file handling, payments, email/notifications, privacy/compliance, cryptography, documentation, engineering leadership, developer environment/CLI. (3) No CSS animation chapter. (4) Frontend and backend security combined into single 'Web Security' chapter. (5) Rendering strategies (SSR/SSG) not covered. (6) No progressive web apps chapter. Wait - actually checking again: PWA is covered under 'Advanced Browser APIs' description mentioning 'Progressive Web App (PWA) offline capabilities' but this is buried. Still, the curriculum is too thin to prepare someone for top-tier roles.

Model A has 36 chapters. Strengths: (1) Good vendor neutrality. (2) Clean, mostly concise titles. (3) Covers core web dev topics. (4) Includes career chapter, microfrontends, technical SEO, monitoring. Issues: (1) Only 36 chapters - insufficient for comprehensive mastery. (2) Missing many important topics: TypeScript, developer environment/CLI, i18n, design systems, infrastructure as code, search systems, domain modeling, event-driven architecture, caching strategies (dedicated), incident management, SRE, cryptography, privacy/compliance, file handling, payments, email, background jobs, ORM, database migrations, API documentation/contracts, system design, load testing. (3) 'Docker and Containers' names Docker in the title - vendor neutrality violation. (4) Some titles could be more concise: 'Career Advancement in Web Development'. (5) CSS split into fundamentals + modern layout + advanced styling + responsive is good, but JavaScript coverage could be deeper. (6) No forms/validation as dedicated chapter. Overall, decent organization but lacks the depth and breadth needed.

Model C provides an incredibly comprehensive and extensive curriculum (86 chapters) that perfectly aligns with the goal of taking a student to the top 1% of the field. It strictly adheres to all negative constraints, including the difficult vendor neutrality rule, by focusing entirely on underlying concepts, protocols, and architectural patterns rather than specific frameworks. The descriptions are perfectly concise and devoid of fluff.

Model D is functionally tied with Model C. It offers an exceptionally deep and thorough curriculum (84 chapters) that covers everything from foundational web concepts to advanced distributed systems and engineering leadership. It perfectly obeys the vendor neutrality constraints (avoiding specific frameworks or banned package managers) and maintains crisp, fluff-free titles and descriptions.

Model A delivers a very strong and well-structured curriculum. It successfully avoids fluff and adheres perfectly to the vendor neutrality rules, accurately describing modern web development concepts without relying on specific framework names. While excellent, it is significantly less comprehensive than Models C and D, covering the field in 36 chapters rather than 80+.

Model B also does a great job following the prompt's formatting and vendor neutrality constraints. It captures a solid full-stack curriculum in 32 chapters without using banned vendor names or unnecessary fluff. Similar to Model A, it simply lacks the extreme depth and comprehensiveness seen in the top models.

Model E provides a good curriculum in terms of content breadth, but it violates a negative constraint by including a 'Capstone' chapter ('Capstone readiness for professional practice'). The prompt explicitly stated: 'No assessments, projects, or capstones.' It also includes minor fluff in a few descriptions.

Model F provides a decent structure but directly violates the negative constraints regarding vendors. The prompt explicitly instructed not to use 'npm' as an example, but Model F includes 'npm ecosystem' in its Chapter 14 description. It also uses slightly more verbose descriptions compared to the top models.

Model G completely ignores the vendor neutrality rule and fails the prompt's explicit instructions. The prompt specifically warned not to use 'npm', 'yarn', or 'pnpm', yet Model G explicitly lists them. It goes on to list almost every major vendor/framework in the industry (React, Vue, Angular, Next.js, Webpack, Vite, Redux, Zustand, etc.). Adherence to constraints is a top penalty criteria, making this output unacceptable.

Most comprehensive and logically sequenced from fundamentals → frontend → backend → data → distributed systems → infra/ops → advanced scaling/modernization → leadership/career. Strong vendor neutrality overall, includes privacy/compliance, supply-chain security, observability/SRE, performance, and modern topics (container queries, edge). Titles/descriptions are mostly concise and professional with minimal fluff; no capstone/projects. Minor nits: occasional acronym-heavy titles (i18n/l10n) and some descriptions slightly long.

Extremely thorough and modern, with excellent depth in HTTP, browser internals, rendering architectures, data systems, security engineering, compliance, SRE, and advanced topics (CRDTs/OT, WebGPU concepts). Very vendor-neutral and well structured. Slight drawbacks vs D: a few titles/descriptions get a bit academic/long, and the overall curriculum may be heavier than needed for “web development” roles (but still aligned with the mastery goal).

Broad and up-to-date coverage across frontend, backend, infra, security, compliance, leadership, and “future trends.” However it violates several prompt constraints: includes explicit vendor names in titles/descriptions (Docker, Kubernetes, PostCSS), and includes capstone-like content (“Capstone readiness…”, “Production-grade portfolio”). Also some descriptions use mild filler (“Role of… history of…”). Strong content but notable rule violations.

Solid modern web-dev scope and progression with good vendor neutrality and concise writing. Gaps for top-tier mastery compared to C/D: limited depth on backend architecture, system design, infra/IaC, privacy/compliance, and software design/leadership beyond a single career chapter. Also includes some arguably non-neutral/dated framing ("utility-first frameworks" in description) but mostly acceptable.

Good breadth and many relevant topics (PWA, WebAssembly, observability, system design, CI/CD). Major prompt violations: heavy vendor/tool naming (Node.js, npm, GitHub, Docker, Docker Compose) and several titles not vendor-neutral (e.g., “Node.js & Package Management”, “Containerization with Docker”). Also some redundancy (two Git collaboration chapters) and some slightly fluffy phrasing (“Building websites…”).

Generally clean, vendor-neutral, and well ordered, with coverage of internet→frontend→backend→ops. But it’s materially less comprehensive than the best curricula: missing deeper browser/platform APIs beyond one chapter, limited security engineering depth, limited data/transaction/performance depth, little on system design specifics, privacy/compliance, and modern frontend rendering approaches (SSR/SSG/ISR). One chapter bundles too much (API Design includes gRPC).

Contains many strong topics, but repeatedly violates vendor-neutrality with extensive specific tool/framework naming (npm/yarn/pnpm, Webpack/Vite/Rollup/Parcel, React/Vue/Angular, Redux/Zustand/React Query, Express, Kubernetes, Helm, Three.js, etc.), including in titles. Also some duplication (WebAssembly appears twice) and some scope creep toward specific ecosystems rather than vendor-neutral principles. Content breadth is high but prompt adherence is poor.
